instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.U7090: What is U7090? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL: What is PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL? This is the voltage coming directly from the charger after going through a transistor. .
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.R7151: What is R7151? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS? This is PPBUS_G3H after passing through a current sense resistor that splits it off from the rest of PPBUS_G3H. The purpose of this is so that we can measure how much current is flowing to this part of the machine..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
So I'm now on my 5th successful board repair. 1 easy and the rest have been hard but I'm making progress and confidence is building.

So this board is liquid damaged.

There was a short on PP3V42. There were also shorts when testing pins on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>. Rookie mistake but I didn't note down the pins that showed a short but believe they were Pins 17+18 and 27+28 and possibly one more.

I tested DCIN on the DCIN board before doing any work and it was a steady 14.4v.

I couldn't see any obvious damage around the board so I removed <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> but the short persisted so I injected 3.3v to see what got hot. I only had the supply on for 5-10 seconds and I could smell something bad so I turned it off and re-inspected the board. Still no obvious damage to anything but on retesting PP3V42, the short had gone and so had any shorts that were on the pins around <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.

I put a brand new <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> on and tested again but now DCIN on the DCIN board is unsteady and flicks between 0-3v and then gives up after 10-20 seconds. I checked <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and reflowed to make sure it was good. I have taken off <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> again and a steady 14.4v returns.

Just tested Pin3 on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and it's  3.8v. This chip is currently off the board.

Resistance between 17+18 is 3.7ohm

Resistance between 27+28 is 20ohm

I'm stuck with what to do next...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message: Is pp3v42 g3h present or not?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message: Nope not present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is the first supply needed for anything to work. What is the resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>? What voltage do you get on pins 6 & 8 of <CHIP>U7090</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7100</CHIP> is still off the board but...

Resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> on 2MÎ© mode =[B] .[/B]445

I don't want to second guess anything so I shall now put back <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> to test <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> voltages of pin 6 and 8? Even when DCIN is all over the place with <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> back on?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
You don't need <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> to check <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> voltages...
Do you get <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL>?
Check <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR>, <DIODE>D7005</DIODE> and resistance to ground after it.
Seems that charger detects leakage and gets in protection mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL> is present at a solid 14.4v

<RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> tests fine at 10ohm
<DIODE>D7005</DIODE> Pin 1 = 0.08v Pin 2 = 14.4v Pin 3 = 14.4v

Resistance to ground after these components is around 150k ohm tested at all points they connect to.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
Check voltages at <CHIP>U7090</CHIP>.
Be aware at corroded traces.
Change it, if no other components are damaged around...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
Didn't see your message until this morning.

<CHIP>U7090</CHIP>
Pin1 = 1.23v
Pin2 = 3.4v
Pin3 = 6.7v
Pin4 = 3.2v
Pin5 = GND
Pin6 = 14.4v
Pin7 = N/A
Pin8 = 14.4v

All tested from the pins of <CHIP>U7090</CHIP>

Can't see any broken or corroded traces around there.

Looks ok, right?

Edit: Realising that PP3V42 is back without <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> on the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message: Now solder good <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and check <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message: Ok, brand new, out of the packet <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> but back to DCIN at the DCIN board pulsing between 0-3/6v then gives up after 10 seconds or so. No <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message: Check resistance to ground at <RESISTOR>R7120</RESISTOR>/50...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7120</RESISTOR> is 35ohm to ground
<RESISTOR>R7150</RESISTOR> is 34ohm to ground

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message: Pull <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> and check again...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
Thanks for all your help.  Removed <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>

<RESISTOR>R7120</RESISTOR> now OL

<RESISTOR>R7150</RESISTOR> now 30 ohm to ground.

DCIN now 14.4v Solid.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.1V Solid.

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.4v Solid.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
Remove F7140 and let see where the low value remains; pin2 I bet...
If yes, check if any secondary coil has the same value to ground.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
Yes you are correct.

Pin1 is 3.3/3.5v
Pin 2 is 0.08v

L3095: Pin1+2 = 0.08v

Both L3095 and Pin 2 of F7140 are 144 Ohm to ground.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
144 should be good on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, when F7140 is closed.
You told us something about 30ohms before...
I expected diode scale measurement after remove F7140, not voltages.
However, check if <TRANSISTOR>Q3080</TRANSISTOR> is shorted.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message: Apologies for the misunderstanding. <TRANSISTOR>Q3080</TRANSISTOR> is not shorted to ground.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
And me never asked you to check short to gorund...
It is shorted D-S???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
Some progress...

<TRANSISTOR>Q3080</TRANSISTOR> led me to the right direction.

<SIGNAL>PP15V_TBT</SIGNAL> was shorted to ground. I have now removed a number of caps on that line and the short is now gone from <SIGNAL>PP15V_TBT</SIGNAL>. 

I put back on F7140 and <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>  and retested. No more dancing 14.4v at DC IN :) But still no green light. Will test the basics again now.

Sorry, shorted D-S? What does it mean?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message: Drain to Source?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
Measurments are now:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 14.4v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.42v

<CHIP>U7100</CHIP>:
Resistance between pins 17+18 is now 80 ohm...
Resistance between pins 27+28 is still 20 ohm.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message: Replace <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> as well as <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> simultaneously, then check ppbus g3h again. Battery side current sensing probably is also causing no green light.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
Thanks, will do.

I just changed <RESISTOR>R7151</RESISTOR> and this got me back to 3.6ohm between 17+18 on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
Changed both at the same time.

<CHIP>U7100</CHIP> was new. <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> from a donor.

Same situation though, nothing better or worse.

<TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>:

Pin1 = 4.57v
Pin2 = 4.57v
Pin3,4,5 GND
Pin 6 = 0v
Pin7 = 4.57v

Let me know if you need pin voltages from <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> or anything else.

Cheers

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
High-side <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> seems to be shorted...
Check if beeps D-S?
When change <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, check if pins 21/24 are properly soldered; if not, <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> gets burnt.
Also, don't forget about <TRANSISTOR>Q3080</TRANSISTOR>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
Yes you were right, <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> D-S was shorted. Swapped for another one and short has gone.
<CHIP>U7100</CHIP> 21/24 are good and have continuity to Pins 1/6 on <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>
<TRANSISTOR>Q3080</TRANSISTOR> D-S was shorted so removed for now.


<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 4.57v

Sorry this is taking so long.... The learning curve is steep but I'm taking it all in!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message: <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> killed <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> now... And probably killed <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
While I was trying to figure out what was going on, I looked for more shorts and found that <CHIP>U3090</CHIP> had shorts to ground on <SIGNAL>TBTBST_SNS1</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>TBTBST_SNS</SIGNAL> so I have removed that chip just in case. The shorts to ground on those lines are now gone. No change in <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>...

<CHIP>U3090</CHIP> is just thunderbolt isn't it? After removing this chip, I tested ground and there is no continuity to ground on pin/pad 37. There is on my donor boards. I'm not sure what this means in regards to troubleshooting. I will continue to look for more shorts. Is this what you call a rabbit hole?

So do you think the right plan of action is look for more shorts and then replace <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> again?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message: <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> still dead, remove and compare diode mode measurements on ppbus g3h to known good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
Thanks for the reply. I don't have a known good board :(  Donor with <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> on the board, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 410 Donor with <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> off the board, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 120

These are my <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> measurements with <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> on the board I'm trying to repair.

<RESISTOR>R7006</RESISTOR> Pin1 = 117
<RESISTOR>R5501</RESISTOR> Pin1 = 118
<TRANSISTOR>Q5500</TRANSISTOR> Pin4 = 119
<RESISTOR>R5450</RESISTOR> Pin 2 = 120
<RESISTOR>R5430</RESISTOR> Pin 2 = 120
F7140 Pin 2 = 120
<RESISTOR>R3080</RESISTOR> Pin 1 = 120
<CAPACITOR>C3080</CAPACITOR> Pin 1 = 120
<TRANSISTOR>Q3080</TRANSISTOR> Pin 4 = 120

These are my <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> measurements with <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> removed from the board I'm trying to repair.

<RESISTOR>R7006</RESISTOR> Pin1 = 109
<RESISTOR>R5501</RESISTOR> Pin1 = 109
<TRANSISTOR>Q5500</TRANSISTOR> Pin4 = 109
<RESISTOR>R5450</RESISTOR> Pin 2 = 109
<RESISTOR>R5430</RESISTOR> Pin 2 = 110
F7140 Pin 2 = 110
<RESISTOR>R3080</RESISTOR> Pin 1 = 111
<CAPACITOR>C3080</CAPACITOR> Pin 1 = 112
<TRANSISTOR>Q3080</TRANSISTOR> Pin 4 = 113

So anything wrong here apart from <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>? Shall I take the <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> from the donor? This will be the third one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
Progress again! :)

So I took that <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> from the donor board and now I have <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>

So it seems that the problem was that the short I found on the <SIGNAL>PP15V_TBT</SIGNAL> circuit was taking out <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>...?

Still no green light so on to more troubleshooting.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
No Title

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8.54v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.34v

But....

This explains the burning smell from when I injected 3.4v originally. I thought it was from that area but couldn't be sure. Also explains no green light. New DC IN Board and Flex cable ordered. Can't find J9500 on ebay so will have to swap from a donor. Thanks for all your help so far. I'm hoping that replacing these parts will resolve everything.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message:
That connector was a pain but all sorted. I have the new DC in board and flex cable connected.  I have green/orange light :) 

It still will not turn on though.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8.5v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> = 8.5v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL> = 8.5v
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL> = 14.9v
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> = 14.9v

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.42v
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.32v

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 5v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.32v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> = 3.32v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> = Dead / Pulsing
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3_EN</SIGNAL> = Dead / Pulsing
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>  = Dead / Pulsing
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = Dead / Pulsing

The pulsing is so quick that the multi meter has trouble recording the values.

Nothing looks corroded here but I have checked all resistors, traces and continuity around Y1905, <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> and <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> and everything checks out. I haven't changed any caps yet.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light
threads.message: Any ideas chaps?
